results.title: We need to talk: employer/employee communication
results.brief_description: This business management resource has been designed by professionals with people management experience in a variety of industries including finance, manufacturing, hospitality and information services. The program is intended for use in a self study or group situation and details seven steps that comprise a successful agenda for meetings, as well as key counselling techniques. These steps and techniques are put into practice through two typical workplace scenarios.

results.title: We grow apricots
results.brief_description: Describes life in an apricot orchard in the irrigation area of the Goulbourn Valley. Shows the full cycle of fruit growing and canning over the year.

results.title: We discovered North Norway
results.brief_description: A train trip in the land of the midnight sun, through more than 500 tunnels. Per Host shows the grandeur of Northern Norway, which until recently very few Norwegians had ever seen. It is a geographical anomaly that here, north of the arctic circle, one can sun-bathe and swim in the fjords amid the towering peaks and plunging ravines.

results.title: We're here now : prostitution
results.brief_description: This program focuses on the myths and realities of prostitution as revealed by seven former prostitutes. These women are struggling to return to the mainstream of society and they meet in a group counselling session that offers mutual support and guidance. This film does not record “street life”. Instead, it shows women coming to grips with the great problems of their lives. It also demonstrates the powerful dynamics of group therapy and the therapeutic value of self-help organisations.

results.title: Wayang shadow puppet
results.material_description: leather, ox horn, bamboo, oil paint
results.brief_description: Wayang Kulit shadow puppets depicting a range of 2D character forms made from animal skin, with an attached central pole and two slender side poles made from ox horn. Puppets are painted with oil and gold paint depicitng details of facial features, head-dresses, jewellery and clothing in a range of bright colours, skin of characters is depicted in gold.

results.title: Grand Théâtre Fantasmagorique shadow play set
results.brief_description: Shadow play sets used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Popular in China for over 2000 years, they were later merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
results.description:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
description_for_label:
Shadow puppetry has been popular in China for more than 2,000 years. Invented to entertain Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty, shadow plays were transported to Europe by travellers in the mid-18th century. There they were known as ombres chinoises (Chinese shadows) and were adapted to tell European stories. Puppeteer François Dominique Séraphin made them popular when he presented them in Paris in 1776, and by 1781 he was dazzling the court at the Palace of Versailles. Even Marie Antoinette admired his work.

Shadow play sets like this one used decorative paper puppets to cast short fables and fairytales. Later they were merged with other innovations, like magic lanterns, to project ghoulish phantasmagoria shows.
